name: 1586_C. Omkar and Determination
description:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. Call a cell in this grid exitable if, starting at that cell, you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells. This includes the cell itself, so all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX

output:
YES

NO

prompt:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. Call a cell in this grid exitable if, starting at that cell, you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells. This includes the cell itself. Therefore, all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX
repair_prompt:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. Call a cell in this grid exitable if, starting at that cell, you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells. This includes the cell itself. Therefore, all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format.  The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX
completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid (np.ndarray): The input grid with 'X' for filled and '.' for empty cells.

    Returns:
        np.ndarray: A 2D numpy array indicating exitability with 'E' for exitable and 'N' for non-exitable.
    """
    n, m = grid.shape
    exitability_grid = np.full((n, m), 'N', dtype=str)

    # Mark the first row and first column as exitable if they are empty
    for i in range(n):
        if grid[i, 0] == '.':
            exitability_grid[i, 0] = 'E'
        else:
            break

    for j in range(m):
        if grid[0, j] == '.':
            exitability_grid[0, j] = 'E'
        else:
            break

    # Fill the rest of the grid based on exitability
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(1, m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.' and (exitability_grid[i-1, j] == 'E' or exitability_grid[i, j-1] == 'E'):
                exitability_grid[i, j] = 'E'

    return exitability_grid

def is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Check if a subgrid is determinable based on the exitability grid.

    Args:
        exitability_grid (np.ndarray): The preprocessed exitability grid.
        x1 (int): The starting column index of the subgrid (1-based).
        x2 (int): The ending column index of the subgrid (1-based).

    Returns:
        str: 'YES' if the subgrid is determinable, 'NO' otherwise.
    """
    # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index
    x1 -= 1
    x2 -= 1

    # Check for any non-determinable pattern in the subgrid
    for j in range(x1, x2):
        for i in range(1, exitability_grid.shape[0]):
            if exitability_grid[i, j] == 'E' and exitability_grid[i-1, j+1] == 'E':
                return 'NO'
    return 'YES'

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Preprocess the grid
    exitability_grid = preprocess_grid(grid)

    # Output results for each query
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray, n: int, m: int) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to identify transitions between exitable and non-exitable cells.

    Args:
        grid (np.ndarray): The grid represented as a numpy array.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.

    Returns:
        np.ndarray: An array indicating columns where transitions occur.
    """
    # Initialize an array to mark transitions
    transitions = np.zeros(m, dtype=bool)
    
    # Iterate over each column starting from the second one
    for col in range(1, m):
        for row in range(n):
            # Check if there is a transition from exitable to non-exitable
            if grid[row, col] == 'X' and grid[row, col - 1] == '.':
                transitions[col] = True
                break
    
    return transitions

def is_determinable(preprocessed_grid: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Determine if the subgrid is determinable based on preprocessed data.

    Args:
        preprocessed_grid (np.ndarray): The preprocessed grid data.
        x1 (int): Starting column index of the query (1-based).
        x2 (int): Ending column index of the query (1-based).

    Returns:
        str: "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, "NO" otherwise.
    """
    # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index for numpy array
    x1 -= 1
    x2 -= 1
    
    # Check if there is any transition in the range [x1+1, x2]
    if np.any(preprocessed_grid[x1+1:x2+1]):
        return "NO"
    return "YES"

def main():
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Preprocess the grid
    preprocessed_grid = preprocess_grid(grid, n, m)

    # Output interface
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_determinable(preprocessed_grid, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_subgrid_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """
    Determines if subgrids specified by queries are determinable based on the exitability of cells.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings, where 'X' is a filled cell and '.' is an empty cell.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each query is a tuple (x1, x2) representing the columns to check.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each query, "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, "NO" otherwise.
    """
    # Precompute the determinability changes
    determinability_changes = [0] * m
    for col in range(1, m):
        for row in range(1, n):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row-1][col-1] == '.':
                determinability_changes[col] = 1
                break

    # Accumulate determinability changes
    for col in range(1, m):
        determinability_changes[col] += determinability_changes[col-1]

    # Process each query
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        if determinability_changes[x2-1] - determinability_changes[x1-1] == 0:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def main():
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Output interface
    results = is_subgrid_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if subgrids are determinable based on exitability of cells.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each a tuple of two integers.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of "YES" or "NO" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Precompute a helper array to identify columns where determinability is broken
    broken_columns = [False] * (m - 1)
    
    # Traverse the grid to fill the broken_columns array
    for row in range(1, n):
        for col in range(m - 1):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row - 1][col + 1] == 'X':
                broken_columns[col] = True

    # Precompute a prefix sum array to quickly answer queries
    prefix_sum = [0] * (m - 1)
    for i in range(1, m - 1):
        prefix_sum[i] = prefix_sum[i - 1] + (1 if broken_columns[i] else 0)

    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index
        x1 -= 1
        x2 -= 1
        # Check if there is any broken column in the range [x1, x2-1]
        if x1 == x2 or prefix_sum[x2 - 1] - (prefix_sum[x1 - 1] if x1 > 0 else 0) == 0:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Call the function and print results
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def process_grid_and_queries(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Processes the grid and queries to determine if subgrids are determinable.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each represented as a tuple of two integers.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each query, "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, "NO" otherwise.
    """
    # Precompute the exitable status for each column
    exitable = [False] * m
    for col in range(m):
        for row in range(n):
            if grid[row][col] == '.':
                exitable[col] = True
                break

    # Precompute the determinability status for each column pair
    determinable = [True] * (m - 1)
    for col in range(m - 1):
        if exitable[col] and exitable[col + 1]:
            determinable[col] = False

    # Process each query
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        if all(determinable[i] for i in range(x1 - 1, x2 - 1)):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Call the function and print results
    results = process_grid_and_queries(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

## main.py

import numpy as np

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: np.ndarray, queries: list) -> list:
    """Determine if subgrids are determinable based on exitability.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (np.ndarray): The grid represented as a numpy array.
        queries (list): List of queries, each a tuple (x1, x2).

    Returns:
        list: List of strings "YES" or "NO" for each query.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine exitability
    exitable = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)

    # Fill the first row and first column
    for i in range(n):
        if grid[i, 0] == '.':
            exitable[i, 0] = True
        else:
            break

    for j in range(m):
        if grid[0, j] == '.':
            exitable[0, j] = True
        else:
            break

    # Fill the rest of the grid
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(1, m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.':
                exitable[i, j] = exitable[i-1, j] or exitable[i, j-1]

    # Precompute determinability information
    determinable = np.zeros(m, dtype=bool)
    for j in range(1, m):
        for i in range(1, n):
            if exitable[i, j] and exitable[i, j-1]:
                determinable[j] = True
                break

    # Answer each query
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        if np.any(determinable[x1:x2]):
            results.append("NO")
        else:
            results.append("YES")

    return results

# Input interface

grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
q = int(input())
queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

# Output interface
results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
for result in results:
    print(result)

## main.py
import numpy as np

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: np.ndarray, queries: list) -> list:
    """Determines if subgrids are determinable based on exitability.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (np.ndarray): The grid represented as a numpy array.
        queries (list): List of queries, each query is a tuple (x1, x2).

    Returns:
        list: List of strings "YES" or "NO" for each query.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to identify exitable cells
    exitable = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)
    
    # Mark exitable cells
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == '.':
                if i == 0 or j == 0 or exitable[i-1][j] or exitable[i][j-1]:
                    exitable[i][j] = True

    # Determine critical points for determinability
    critical_points = np.zeros(m, dtype=bool)
    for j in range(1, m):
        for i in range(1, n):
            if exitable[i][j] and not exitable[i-1][j] and not exitable[i][j-1]:
                critical_points[j] = True
                break

    # Process each query
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        if np.any(critical_points[x1:x2]):
            results.append("NO")
        else:
            results.append("YES")

    return results

from typing import List
## main.py
import numpy as np

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: np.ndarray, queries: list) -> list:
    """Determine if subgrids specified by queries are determinable based on exitability.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (np.ndarray): 2D numpy array representing the grid with 'X' for filled and '.' for empty cells.
        queries (list): List of tuples, each containing two integers representing the column range of the subgrid.

    Returns:
        list: List of strings "YES" or "NO" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine exitability
    exitable = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)
    
    # Determine exitability for the first row and first column
    for i in range(n):
        exitable[i, 0] = (grid[i, 0] == '.')
    for j in range(m):
        exitable[0, j] = (grid[0, j] == '.')
    
    # Fill the exitability grid
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(1, m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.':
                exitable[i, j] = exitable[i-1, j] or exitable[i, j-1]
    
    # Precompute determinability information
    determinable = np.zeros(m, dtype=bool)
    for j in range(1, m):
        determinable[j] = not np.any(exitable[:, j] & exitable[:, j-1])
    
    # Process each query
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        if x1 == x2 or np.all(determinable[x1:x2]):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")
    
    return results

# Input interface

grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
q = int(input())
queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

# Output interface
results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
for result in results:
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray, n: int, m: int) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid: A numpy array representing the grid with 'X' for filled and '.' for empty cells.
        n: Number of rows in the grid.
        m: Number of columns in the grid.

    Returns:
        A numpy array with the same dimensions as grid, where each cell is marked as 'E' if exitable and 'N' otherwise.
    """
    # Initialize the preprocessed grid with 'N' for non-exitable cells
    preprocessed_grid = np.full((n, m), 'N', dtype=str)

    # Mark exitable cells
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.':
                if i == 0 or j == 0 or preprocessed_grid[i-1, j] == 'E' or preprocessed_grid[i, j-1] == 'E':
                    preprocessed_grid[i, j] = 'E'
    
    return preprocessed_grid

def is_subgrid_determinable(preprocessed_grid: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Determine if the subgrid specified by columns x1 to x2 is determinable.

    Args:
        preprocessed_grid: A numpy array representing the preprocessed grid with exitability information.
        x1: Starting column index of the subgrid (1-based index).
        x2: Ending column index of the subgrid (1-based index).

    Returns:
        'YES' if the subgrid is determinable, 'NO' otherwise.
    """
    # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index for numpy array access
    x1 -= 1
    x2 -= 1

    # Check for determinability by ensuring no two consecutive columns have a transition from 'E' to 'N'
    for j in range(x1, x2):
        if np.any((preprocessed_grid[:, j] == 'E') & (preprocessed_grid[:, j+1] == 'N')):
            return 'NO'
    
    return 'YES'

def main():
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Preprocess the grid
    preprocessed_grid = preprocess_grid(grid, n, m)

    # Output interface
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(preprocessed_grid, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import numpy as np

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: np.ndarray, queries: list) -> list:
    """Determine if subgrids specified by queries are determinable.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (np.ndarray): 2D array representing the grid with 'X' for filled and '.' for empty cells.
        queries (list): List of tuples representing the queries with column indices.

    Returns:
        list: List of strings "YES" or "NO" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine exitable cells
    exitable = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)
    
    # Mark exitable cells starting from the top row and left column
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.':
                if i == 0 or j == 0 or exitable[i-1, j] or exitable[i, j-1]:
                    exitable[i, j] = True

    # Precompute the determinability for each column
    determinable = np.zeros(m, dtype=bool)
    for j in range(1, m):
        determinable[j] = np.any(exitable[:, j] & ~exitable[:, j-1])

    # Process each query
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        if np.all(determinable[x1:x2]):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")
    
    return results

# Input interface
n, m = map(int, input().split())
grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
q = int(input())
queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

# Output interface
results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
for result in results:
    print(result)

We will use a preprocessing step to efficiently determine the exitable cells in the grid. By leveraging numpy for fast array operations, we can quickly identify exitable cells and use this information to answer queries about determinability. The key challenge is to handle large grid sizes and high query volumes efficiently, which numpy is well-suited for due to its optimized performance for numerical data.
examples:
Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX
